ORDER

The petitioner sought anticipatory bail in Crime
No.311/2017 of Valancheri Police Station for offences
punishable under sections 341, 448, 323, 354 and 506(1)
read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code.

2. The allegation of the prosecution was that on
28.10.2017 at 21.15 hours, the accused trespassed into
the house of the defacto complainant restrained her, her
mother and grand mother. Thereafter, they were beaten
up. There is a further allegation that the third accused
tore her nightly and molested her. When the anticipatory
bail application came up before the learned Sessions
Judge, the learned Sessions Judge noticed that the
accused 1 to 4 attacked the defacto complainant and
others since she had _ claimed Rs.4,75,000/- as
maintenance granted by the Family Court. It appears
that the petitioners are the husband and in-laws of the
defacto complainant. Having considered the entire facts,

2017/KER/49780
Crl.M.C.No.8454 of 2017
2

the learned Judge by order dated 18.11.2017, which is
produced as Annexure-A, granted bail, inter alia, on a
condition that he shall remit 50% of the arrears of the
maintenance if any before the Family Court and produce

the receipt before the investigating officer before
executing the bond. That portion of the order is under
challenge in the present proceedings.

3. After hearing the learned counsel for the
petitioner and the learned Public Prosecutor though the
intention of the court below in imposing such a condition
that may appear to be prima facie appreciable, legally it
does not appear to be sustainable. Granting of bail,
should not be dependant on a condition of deposit of the
portion of the money in a different proceedings between
parties. It was submitted by the learned counsel for the
first petitioner that the total amount due is only
Rs.2,43,000/- out of he has deposited a sum of
Rs.1,02,000/-. A statement which has been filed by the
learned counsel for the petitioner to that effect. Without
